Award.AwardTitle: High-Resolution Integrated Ultrasound and Microwave Imaging for Early-Stage Breast Cancer Diagnosis

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
CBET-0756338, Moghaddam

The PI proposes combining two non-ionizing imaging modalities, ultrasound and microwave, to take advantage of the synergistic imaging properties that result. The ultrasound component will provide information regarding shape and location of unidentified tissue masses. The microwave component utilizes nonlinear time domain inverse scattering techniques and would provide quantitative information regarding the dielectric constant and conductivity of the tissue. Unlike the current systems that require verification, the proposed imaging system could provide a definitive diagnosis of the tissue mass /lesion significantly reducing the percent of false positive and false negative reports. When used in combination with the ultrasound shape functions it could provide an imaging system with increased resolution, spatial fidelity, and ability to quantify and characterize the tissue type. Initially the US and MW measurements will be taken simultaneously and independently during the early stages of algorithm development. The proposed imaging system could possibly provide a resolution of less than 5mm.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this project was to develop a combined microwave-ultrasound (MW-US) imaging system, focused at early-stage breast-cancer diagnosis, with high resolution and high specificity not previously possible. The idea is to use information from one of these nonionizing modalities to guide the other, therefore to take advantage of the synergies of the two modalities. Initially, theoretical analyses and simulations were performed for each of the two modalities. We showed that incorporating prior information from ultrasound imagery into microwave images (or vice versa) significantly improves the ability to retrieve higher resolution and more accurate maps of the imaged domain, and began developing the experimental set up for the microwave imaging system.

Full experimental demonstrations of the microwave imaging system were performed. Initially, two experiments setups were developed, one a “free-space” experiment to demonstrate our new absolute calibration technique to convert S-parameters to complex-valued field quantities and to form preliminary images when objects are in air, and the other was a measurement system (not an imaging system) using a biologically representative matching medium to show the end-to-end feasibility of the microwave measurements and in particular for time-domain measurements.  Then the matching medium was used in a cavity-based imaging setup that we developed, which can be considered a preclinical prototype imager. The self-contained absolute calibration scheme was adapted to this new setup and geometry, and several experiments were performed to show the utility of this imager. Ultrasound measurements and calibration were also carried out in parallel, and imaging results with the source calibration scheme were obtained. The ultrasound results were promising, and identified limitations in the existing ultrasound measurement systems that should be resolved with further experimentation.

The underlying theoretical analyses that enable the quantitative imaging of tissue electrical properties have been reported in several papers. These included the development of a self-contained absolute calibration scheme based on multipole expansions of the fields transmitted and received through the antennas, implementation of the Born iterative method combined with the Born series forward scattering solution, and a regularization scheme using the concepts of weighted vector spaces to arrive at a multivariate covariance cost function.

During final year of the project, these developments were used in a preclinical prototype imaging system in a cavity geometry. Figure 1 shows the setup, including a 12-sided cylindrical cavity with embedded antennas, switching matrix, matching fluid that fills the cavity and enhances the coupling of electromagnetic waves to the tissue phantom, network-analyzer based transmit/receive data collection system, and mechanical structure including a precision rotation stage. The cylindrical cavity has three rows of antennas to enable better capture of the 3D target properties. 

We demonstrated the use of a numerical characterization technique for this breast imaging system prototype. We used HFSS to numerically estimate the incident fields of the antennas in a cavity geometry and formally linked them to an S-parameter-based inverse scattering algorithm and experimental setup. The imaging algorithm was the Born Iterative Method and recovered both numerical and experimental test objects with some success. Figure 2 shows a numerical phantom and results of its reconstruction in simulation. Figure 3 shows the arrangement of two spherical targets used for experimental validation of the imaging algorithm and setup, and the reconstructed images of permittivity, clearly showing the location and contrast properties of the targets with high accuracy.
